id="T8AgE8NFaqKm2SE2sQ5F-5" value="src 1" style="whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;aspect=fixed;" parent="T8AgE8NFaqKm2SE2sQ5F-19" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="20" y="10" width="80" height="80" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="T8AgE8NFaqKm2SE2sQ5F-6" value="src 2" style="whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;aspect=fixed;" parent="T8AgE8NFaqKm2SE2sQ5F-19" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="20" y="110" width="80" height="80" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="T8AgE8NFaqKm2SE2sQ5F-20" value="Learning 3: Omnibar src is a special case of course. <br>This needs protection, since <br>everyone has access to .open in JS<br><br>It's feels like an exception, where we shouldn't "send" the cookies. <br>But, it's still within the "src" primary identifier realm, <br>since the link component or .open (the page console) <br>can be treated as a component. And components <br>shouldn't be able to create a situation where they <br>affect cookie get/set for other src. <br>Of course, if the components came in the HTML, that's fine.<br><br>However, since anchor tag is a major component, <br>we should be able to relax this rule (which was the default). <br>But strict mode is now available." style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;rounded=0;" parent="H6Bev_J5mzgq0XRdQ2ko-4" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry y="387" width="370" height="230" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="T8AgE8NFaqKm2SE2sQ5F-21" value="Learning 1: components interact with their own cookies, <br>and have nothing to do with the page src" style="text;html=1;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;" parent="H6Bev_J5mzgq0XRdQ2ko-4" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="25" y="285" width="320" height="40" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> <mxCell id="H6Bev_J5mzgq0XRdQ2ko-5" value="- Cookies are sent on every relevant request automatically by the browser as a header.<br>- Setting:<br><span style=""><span style="white-space: pre;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span>-&nbsp;Cookies may be set by the server<br><span style=""><span style="white-space: pre;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span>- Cookies may be set by the client<br><span style=""><span style="white-space: pre;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span>- Cookies may be set by the client such that client side JS cannot access it (access through browser internal UI is still possible)<br>&nbsp; &nbsp; - A cookie has a value and a config<br>- Cookies may be invalidated by the server or the client JS (unless it cannot access it). Of course, invalidation through browser internal UI is always possible.<br><br>Note: browser level UI is not scriptable." style="text;html=1;align=left;verticalAlign=middle;resizable=0;points=[];autosize=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;labelBorderColor=default;spacingTop=0;" parent="1" vertex="1"> <mxGeometry x="0.5" y="80" width="850" height="140" as="geometry" /> </mxCell> </root> </mxGraphModel> </diagram> </mxfile>

div.div:
Learning 3: Omnibar src is a special case of course.
This needs protection, since
everyone has access to .open in JS
It's feels like an exception, where we shouldn't "send" the cookies.
But, it's still within the "src" primary identifier realm,
since the link component or .open (the page console)
can be treated as a component. And components
shouldn't be able to create a situation where they
affect cookie get/set for other src.
Of course, if the components came in the HTML, that's fine.
However, since anchor tag is a major component,
we should be able to relax this rule (which was the default).
But strict mode is now available.

switch.text: Learning 3: Omnibar src is a special case of course....

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 531px; margin-left: 222px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(240, 240, 240); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: nowrap;

div.div:
Learning 1: components interact with their own cookies,
and have nothing to do with the page src

switch.text: Learning 1: components interact with their own cookie...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 134px; margin-left: 2px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(240, 240, 240); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; border: 1px solid rgb(240, 240, 240); white-space: nowrap;

div.div:
- Cookies are sent on every relevant request automatically by the browser as a header.
- Setting:
- Cookies may be set by the server
- Cookies may be set by the client
- Cookies may be set by the client such that client side JS cannot access it (access through browser internal UI is still possible)
- A cookie has a value and a config
- Cookies may be invalidated by the server or the client JS (unless it cannot access it). Of course, invalidation through browser internal UI is always possible.
Note: browser level UI is not scriptable.

switch.text: - Cookies are sent on every relevant request automatically by the browser as a header....
